results.title: Xmas cruise
results.brief_description: A pictorial account of the ‘Katoomba” and her passengers among the islands of the pacific. Includes images of downtown Sydney in the 30s and 40s. Double Decker buses and trams feature. Photographed by Vin Alford.

results.title: Xena: Warrior princess. Season 2. Eps. 15-16
results.brief_description: Episodes 15 (A Day in the Life) and 16 (For Him the Bell Tolls) from the second series of the groundbreaking television series about Xena, a tough female warrior struggling to come to terms with her evil past, and Gabrielle, her devoted sidekick. As a physically strong, independent woman, the character of Xena has been adopted as a feminist icon of popular culture. The implication within the subtext of the show that Xena and Gabrielle might be more than ‘just good friends’ has led many adult viewers to read the couple as lovers. “A Day in the Life” follows Xena and Gabrielle as they spend a typical day together defeating giants and warlords and fighting off potential suitors. Heavy in “lesbian subtext”, the interactions between the two women in this comic episode has been likened by fans to the banter between long term couples like Tracey and Hepburn in their classic screwball comedies. “For Him the Bell Tolls” sees Joxer, the foolish wannabe warrior who follows Xena and Gabrielle around, transformed by Aphrodite into a dashing war hero tasked with stealing a princess’s heart away from her betrothed. Gabrielle must intervene to reverse Aphrodite’s mischievous spell. This episode is a homage to “The Court Jester” featuring Danny Kaye.

results.title: Xena: Warrior princess. Season 2. Eps. 11-12
results.brief_description: Episodes 11 (Here she comes…Miss Amphipolis) and 12 (Destiny) from the second series of the groundbreaking television series about Xena, a female warrior struggling to come to terms with her evil past, and Gabrielle, her faithful sidekick. Together the two women roam across ancient Greece, battling warlords and righting wrongs. Filmed on location in New Zealand, the series is highly postmodern in tone, mixing martial-arts-inspired action sequences with ‘camp’ humour and contemporary cultural references. As a physically strong, independent woman, the character of Xena has been adopted as a feminist icon of popular culture. The implication within the subtext of the show that Xena and Gabrielle might be more than ‘just good friends’ has led many adult viewers to read the couple as lovers. In the gender-bending comic episode “Here she comes…Miss Amphipolis” Xena masquerades as a beauty contestant, and enters the “Miss Known World” beauty pageant in order to discover the identity of saboteurs. A drag queen wins the contest. “Destiny”, the first of a dramatic two part episode, sees Xena suffering a near fatal wound. In a delirious state she revisits some of the experiences that shaped her life including her first encounter with Julius Caeser, and her relationship with a mysterious women. A beautifully photographed episode directed by Robert Tapert, the creator of the series.

results.title: Xena: Warrior princess. Season 1. Eps. 21-22
results.brief_description: Episodes twenty-one (“The Greater good”) and twenty-two (“Callisto”) of the first season of the groundbreaking television series about Xena, a female warrior struggling to come to terms with her evil past, and Gabrielle, her faithful sidekick. Together the two women roam across ancient Greece, battling warlords and righting wrongs. Filmed on location in New Zealand, the series was created as a spinoff from the popular fantasy-action series ‘Hercules: The Legendary Journeys’. Highly postmodern in tone, the series mixed martial-arts-inspired action sequences with ‘camp’ humour, contemporary cultural references, and a wild disregard for historical accuracy. As a physically strong, independent woman, the character of Xena has been adopted as a feminist icon of popular culture. The implication within the subtext of the show that Xena and Gabrielle might be more than ‘just good friends’ has led many viewers to read the couple as lesbian lovers. “The Greater good”. When Xena is incapacitated and left near death after being struck by a poisoned dart, Gabrielle is forced to impersonate the Warrior Princess in order to protect a group of innocent villagers. In “Callisto”, Xena is once again reminded of the sins of her past when a malicious female warrior, whose family was killed by Xena’s former army, exacts her revenge on the Warrior Princess by impersonating her. This was the first appearance of the character of Callisto, known amongst “Xena” fans as “psycho-Barbie”, who appeared as Xena’s evil nemesis in a number of subsequent episodes. This episode also features one of a number of action-sequences borrowed from Hong Kong action movies that appear throughout the series. In this case the sequence where Xena and Callisto fight on an elaborate series of ladders is taken directly from “Once upon a time in China” (1991).

results.title: Xena: Warrior princess. Season 1. Eps. 19-20
results.brief_description: Episodes nineteen (“Altared States”) and twenty (“Ties that bind”) of the first season of the groundbreaking television series about Xena, a female warrior struggling to come to terms with her evil past and her faithful sidekick, the bard, Gabrielle. Together the two women roam across ancient Greece, battling warlords and righting wrongs. Highly postmodern in tone, the series mixes martial-arts-inspired action sequences with ‘camp’ humour, lesbian subtext, contemporary cultural references, and a wild disregard for historical accuracy. In “Altared States”, a clever reworking of the Abraham-Isaac story, Xena and Gabrielle intervene to prevent the sacrifice of a young boy by his father in the name of the “Supreme Deity” worshipped by a group of zealots. They discover that the older son has fabricated this God in order to replace his brother as his father’s successor. This was the first episode to insert self-conscious subtextual references in response to fans of the show who read the relationship between Xena and Gabrielle as a romantic one. “Ties that bind”: Xena rescues a mysterious warrior who later claims to be her estranged father. But the reunion is anything but happy, as a suspicious Xena tries to find out if the man’s claims are true.

results.title: Xena: Warrior princess. Season 1. Eps. 09-10
results.brief_description: Episodes nine (“Death in chains”) and ten (“Hooves and harlots”) of the first season of the groundbreaking television series about Xena, a female warrior struggling to come to terms with her evil past and her faithful sidekick, the bard, Gabrielle. Together the two women roam across ancient Greece, battling warlords and righting wrongs. Highly postmodern in tone, the series mixes martial-arts-inspired action sequences with ‘camp’ humour, lesbian subtext, contemporary cultural references, and a wild disregard for historical accuracy. In “Death in chains” the arrogant King Sisyphus traps Celesta, the messenger of death, in his castle after she arrives to escort him to the underworld. Unless Celesta is released and her eternal flame restored, those who would die in normal circumstances are condemned to eternal suffering. Xena must find a way to free her before her flame is extinguished forever. “Hooves and Harlots” is the first episode to feature the Amazons and the Centaurs, two groups who paid major roles in subsequent episodes. It is also the episode in which Xena’s sidekick Gabrielle, initially a naive and idealistic village girl who insisted on tagging along with Xena, comes into her own. After trying to save the life of a young Amazon woman, Gabrielle is given right of caste, becomes an Amazon princess and learns how to fight. With Xena’s help she prevents an all-out war between the Amazons and the Centaurs that is being stirred up by an evil warlord with vested interests.

results.title: Xena: Warrior princess. Season 1. Eps. 01-02
results.brief_description: The first two episodes of the groundbreaking television series about Xena, a female warrior struggling to come to terms with her evil past, and Gabrielle, her faithful sidekick. Together the two women roam across ancient Greece, battling warlords and righting wrongs. Filmed on location in New Zealand, the series was created as a spinoff from the popular fantasy-action series ‘Hercules: The Legendary Journeys’. Highly postmodern in tone, the series mixes martial-arts-inspired action sequences with ‘camp’ humour, contemporary cultural references, and a wild disregard for historical accuracy. As a physically strong, independent woman, the character of Xena has been adopted as a feminist icon of popular culture. The implication within the subtext of the show that Xena and Gabrielle might be more than ‘just good friends’ has led many viewers to read the couple as lesbian lovers. In episode one, ‘Sins of the past’, Xena journeys homeward, determined to make amends for her past sins, but her efforts to begin a new life are challenged by the vengeful warlord, Draco. In episode two, ‘Chariots of war’, Xena is wounded after saving a young boy. Rescued by the boy’s father, she is taken into town to recuperate but many of the townsfolk are unhappy about her presence there.

results.title: Xanadu
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Lawrence Gordon and Robert Greenwald
results.brief_description: Disco, rollerskates, ELO and 1940s meets 1980s courtesy of Olivia Newton-John and Gene Kelly combined in this cult, kitsch, musical fantasy. Kira (Olivia Newton-John) is a Greek muse despatched to Earth to inspire young artist, Sonny Malone (Michael Beck), realise his dream of starting up a disco rollerskating rink called Xanadu. She teams him up with Danny McGuire (Gene Kelly), an ex big club band member and former recipient of Kira’s magical influence. Sonny and Danny merge their styles and generations as Kira and Sonny challenge the laws of nature by falling in love. From this threadbare plot emerges a time capsule of 1980s music, fashion, and sensibility that has been simultaneously loved and loathed by viewers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Universal Pictures, Lawrence Gordon and Robert Greenwald

She teams him up with Danny McGuire (Gene Kelly), an ex big club band member and former recipient of Kira’s magical influence. Sonny and Danny merge their styles and generations as Kira and Sonny challenge the laws of nature by falling in love. From this threadbare plot emerges a time capsule of 1980s music, fashion, and sensibility that has been simultaneously loved and loathed by viewers.
